newsitem.title: RUSSIA: New Russian customs rules shake air cargo market.
newsitem.headline: New Russian customs rules shake air cargo market.

text.p: Russian air freight forwarders called on customs authorities on Friday to revoke new rules that have caused a backlog of millions of dollars worth of imported cargo in Moscow since they were imposed last month.
The forwarders said however they could not provide more detailed estimates of the cost of the backlog at this stage.

"The air cargo market may be destroyed," Boris Panchenko, senior cargo manager at forwarding firm Eruslan said, unless a new rule forcing importers to pay duties on arrival at Moscow rather than at their final destination, was scrapped.
"The new regime for transit cargo through Moscow has frozen many air cargo contracts," Igor Mordvinov, senior sales manager of Burlington Air Express Moscow, told Reuters.
But he acknowledged: "It is not clear that the customs will scrap these rules or change them soon."

A State Customs Committee spokesman said the authorities had changed the rules because cargo arriving at Moscow was "disappearing" en route to provincial destinations, leaving duty unpaid. "We had big losses," he said.

The result for the forwarders, however, was that many clients had simply halted transit shipments through Moscow, said Nikolai Belyayev, sales manager of EMS Garant Post, a forwarder for Air France, KLM and ANA Cargo.

"We see that cargo volume has dropped in the last two weeks," he said, adding that the new rule was "illogical" and should be scrapped. The forwarders had seen significant loss of business since it was introduced on March 20, he said.
Panchenko, at Eruslan, said the customs rule had forced client importers from the Russian provinces to travel in person to the capital to clear their cargo through customs.
"It's a big problem because it's costing them time and money," he said. Clients were looking for alternative routes to ship cargo avoiding Moscow. "But this is not easy," he added.
Panchenko said the rules ought to prove profitable for Western airlines which operated direct cargo and passenger flights from western Europe to provincial Russian destinations.
"Lufthansa and other Western carriers are in favour now," Panchenko said. Lufthansa serves a number of major cities in central Russia and Siberia from Germany.
